in the workflow, could it be that there is a long time between the moment Backup is instantiated and backup actually started? I'm just wondering if it makes more sense to get the backup timestamp at the time of start() instead.
Good point. I moved the this.timestamp = runtime.getAddressSpaceView().getLogTail(); to method start().

if this throws a TrimmedException, do we want to stop and crash all backup, or print the error and backup the ones that don't have issues? not saying if it's correct or not, just making sure which is the behavior that we want.

Good point. I thinking failing the whole backup would be easier for users to implement some retry mechanism. We don't want users to say backup 6 in 10 tables (because the other 4 failed) and backup the remaining 4 tables in a second run, and then merge the two tar files. I understand your point is that if some tables failed at least we don't lose other successful backups. I think we need some comments from Graham to see how they want to handle this exception.
since backup/restore is a workflow running occasionally should this be set to info?
Done. Thanks.
do we want to preserve the file or delete original after in the TAR? or is this done in the cleanup?
Those files are under backupTempDirPath and are deleted in cleanup() at the end of the whole process.

we're restoring whatever is available in that TAR... imagine someone manipulates that TAR and removes some files... should we have a validation similar to the case of Backup, where if a list of streams to restore is given, or tagged streams is specified as preferred option, at the end we consider successful, if and only if we have restored everything requested in the API.

The requirement for restore is to restore whatever inside the given TAR file. We used to let users input a list of tables they want to restore in the restore API but Graham's team said they don't really need that feature. That's why we remove that parameter and just restore whatever they give us.
on similar lines that the backed up tar file can get corrupted, should we add a checksum to the tar file?  On restore, verify if the checksum is as expected and fail if not?
info?
Done. Thanks.
I think this actually has to do with my comment.. should we solve this now?

I haven't decided what to check as verification. Also since it's a nice-to-have feature and not currently asked for by Graham's team, I think it might be better to not put too many efforts in this very first backup restore PR.
can we add an explicit log.info stating: 'Completed restore of table {}' ... (something in that line)
Changed to log.info("completed restore of table {} with {} numEntries", streamId, numEntries);. Thanks.
we only have a test case where all tables are tagged as required for backup, can we have a test that combines non-tagged with tagged? so we validate that it is selective.
Done. Thanks.

I think we can add a bit of more tests to cover more scenarios:

A test where the TAR is deleted before restore, to validate exception is thrown..
A test where only a subset of specified streamIds are backed (not all, like in test 1)
A test where the log is trimmed before backup...

Some other tests I thought would be relevant are:

Specify a StreamX for backup (through the API where streams for backup are given) which has never been open by any client (not in the registry).
Specify a StreamY for backup which is open but empty, so we validate that empty tables are restored with no issues.
They are all very good test cases. I'll add them soon.

nodes.bodyText: where is BACKUP_TEMP_DIR defined?

The backup temporary directory is generated by this line of code:
this.backupTempDirPath = Files.createTempDirectory(BACKUP_TEMP_DIR_PREFIX).toString(); (https://docs.oracle.com/javase/8/docs/api/java/nio/file/Files.html#createTempDirectory-java.lang.String-java.nio.file.attribute.FileAttribute...-)
The directory is created in system default temp path.
where is BACKUP_TEMP_DIR defined?
as explained above

instead of repeating the below code, you can call the previous constructor from here -
Backup(filePath, getTaggedTables(), runtime)
Backup() is constructor. Calling this(filePath, getTaggedTables(), runtime) will trigger Error:(83, 24) java: cannot reference this before supertype constructor has been called
should we add a null check aslo?
Just added null check in start() and abort backup in case of null streamIDs. Thanks!

in that case, is there no way to backup data which is checkpointed and trimmed?
As discussed, this happens extremely rarely. In case of such scenario, users can do a retry.

Done. Thanks.

Done. Thanks.
do we want to print names of all tables?  this will only print the list reference, right?
is it possible that the user-specified path for backup tar is inside this temp directory?

It is somehow possible. But considering the temporary directory is actually created in the middle of Backup process with a prefix in dir nameFiles.createTempDirectory(BACKUP_TEMP_DIR_PREFIX), I think it's really unlike that someone would give this exact filePath if not being deliberate.
nit - indentation

Interesting. I tried to make it align but line 136 and 137 are actually auto-indented by pressing Enter from the line above them. Line 136 is aligned with FileInputStream and line 137 is indented as an inner scope code block.
it seems we read multiple SMR entries in each iteration.  Should this be incremented by only 1?
Good point. Changed to numEntries += smrEntries.size();
does this mean there is no backed up data for this stream?  If so, should we break here instead of continuing?
continue and break should have the same effect here. continue will go back to while(fileInput.available() > 0) and then exits the loop.
Question - do we ever delete the backup tar file?  I think we dont.  Is it the expected behavior?

I think this is expected behavior. The tar file is provided by user and I think is better to be users' responsibility to collect or remove. Also deleting such tar file might be unexpected  for some users if they didn't read documents carefully. It's just safer to keep it instead of deleting it.
should we also clear the stream and get rid of any ongoing updates?

When this particular SMREntry gets committed it will clear the stream to empty. Also, the team using this Restore guarantees that all services are shut down during restore so there will be no more ongoing updates after the clear request.
